image.altText: Two women hugging. Neither of their faces are visible

items.synopsis: A landmark inquiry made almost 200 recommendations for protecting Tasmanian children from abuse. Those who shared their pain will ensure the government now follows through.

title.children: 'Finally, they have to listen': Victim-survivors react after 191 inquiry recommendations made

image.altText: A composite of four people's faces - three women and one man.

items.synopsis: Over nine weeks of hearings, witnesses told of how a paedophile nurse was left to operate inside a children's ward, how school children were not believed, and about widescale abuse facing youth detainees in a "monster" prison.

title.children: In their words: The harrowing stories told to Tasmania's commission of inquiry

image.altText: A police officer writes in a notebook as a young woman stands in the background

items.synopsis: A prison sentence of more than 18 years was handed down to a perpetrator of family violence against multiple partners. Advocates say it's a sign attitudes are shifting — but the work isn't done.

title.children: Advocates pleased to see coercive control taken seriously as man given 18-year jail sentence

image.altText: A composite image of Anthony Albanese and Jacinta Nampijinpa Price

items.synopsis: Yes and No advocates will spend the first full day of the formal Voice to Parliament referendum campaign targeting the swing states of South Australia and Tasmania.

title.children: Tasmania, South Australia focus of Voice advocates on first full day of formal campaign

image.altText: A young white woman leaning next to a house window

items.synopsis: Ruby Callaghan has tried for six months to stop one of the world's retail giants from charging her unwanted fees. The federal government says it is looking at introducing legislation, known as "don't be a jerk laws", to help curb the issue.

title.children: Ruby tried to cancel her Amazon account in March, but got stuck in a 'subscription trap'

image.altText: A woman leans against a tree with a Redfern sign behind her.

items.synopsis: In Western Sydney, the No campaign is targeting the undecided and Yes voters are hoping against heartache.

title.children: How 'the Black capital of Australia' will be voting in the Voice referendum

image.altText: Anthony Albanese standing in front of "VOTE YES" branding as he announces the date of the Voice to Parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Whichever way the referendum goes, there will be enormous ramifications for reconciliation and Indigenous advancement. There will be political consequences felt all the way to the next election — and the next six weeks absolutely matter, writes David Speers.

title.children: The differences between a referendum and an election help explain why the Voice's Yes camp is so confident

image.altText: A view of the Liddell coal-fired power plant from across a lake, with swans in the foreground

items.synopsis: Much of the national power grid is facing substantial reliability problems over the next decade, and as soon as this summer, without rapid investment in both electricity generation and transmission.

title.children: National energy grid facing peak pressures over hotter months

image.altText: A woman standing in a vacant lot

items.synopsis: Multiple Victorian home owners have made complaints to the state's building authority over allegedly defective works they say have left them hundreds of thousands of dollars out of pocket.

title.children: Andrea thought she was building the home she'd retire in. $1 million later, she and her family are in a 'nightmare'

image.altText: A German Empire flag.

items.synopsis: Born out of anti-government rallies during the pandemic, authorities say Germany's Reichsbürger movement is a growing threat. And it's forging ties with one of the country's biggest political parties.

title.children: A fake state: The wild theory gaining traction in Germany

image.altText: The garden as it appeared in a 2020 listing

items.synopsis: Errol Stewart and his family company are facing charges over garden works at a heritage-listed Hobart property. Mr Stewart says the works were urgent, but the council says the works have damaged the heritage significance of the site.

title.children: 'It's my garden': Prominent developer defends changing heritage-listed garden without permit

image.altText: A group of pedestrians walking along a footpath by the Yarra River on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: The approaching new season follows a dry winter for the east coast, and records broke in major cities for the warmest winter on record.

title.children: Spring will prove to bring scorching temperatures and below average rainfall

image.altText: A group of four people dressed in white PPE and wearing red vests stand around an unmarked grave.

items.synopsis: Sudan's body retrievers pick through debris in a war zone to find the bodies of those killed in the country’s months-long civil war. The task is filled with hazards and could be deadly.

title.children: Stray bullets, falling debris and the risk of infection: The deadly task to bury Sudan's dead

image.altText: Rudy Giuliiani with cameras in his face and a peacock in front of a moon

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Rudy Giuliani found liable for defamation, rare blue moon seen around the world. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ukraine's military has confirmed six Ukrainian servicemen have been killed aboard two helicopters while "carrying out missions." Local media reports the incident occurred near Kramatorsk, where much of the fighting has been taking place since Russia's invasion 18 months ago. Reports suggest the two helicopters were "completely destroyed" and bodies have been found at the crash site. Officials say a service for the men will take place on Thursday local time.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ukraine's military confirms multiple deaths after helicopter crash

children.content: Ukraine's military has confirmed six Ukrainian servicemen have been killed aboard two helicopters while "carrying out missions."
Local media reports the incident occurred near Kramatorsk,
where much of the fighting has been taking place since Russia's invasion 18 months ago.
Reports suggest the two helicopters were "completely destroyed" and bodies have been found at the crash site.
Officials say a service for the men will take place on Thursday local time.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The prime minister says he's convinced voters in the crucial state of Tasmania will vote Yes in the Voice referendum. Anthony Albanese will visit Hobart and Launceston on the first full day of campaigning since confirming the poll will be held on October 14. After spending yesterday in Hobart, No campaign leaders will head to Adelaide today — in a further sign Tasmania and South Australia are shaping up to be key states in the vote. Mr Albanese has told Triple-M Radio he's confident the referendum will succeed. "I am convinced Tasmanians will vote Yes," he said. "I will be with the Premier Jeremy Rockliff this morning, and then with Bridget Archer in Launceston this afternoon, both of them being strong Yes supporters."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM: 'Tasmanians will vote Yes'

children.content: The prime minister says he's convinced voters in the crucial state of Tasmania will vote Yes in the
Voice referendum
Anthony Albanese will visit Hobart and Launceston on the first full day of campaigning since confirming the poll will be held on October 14.
After spending yesterday in Hobart, No campaign leaders will head to Adelaide today — in a further sign Tasmania and South Australia are shaping up to be key states in the vote.
Mr Albanese has told Triple-M Radio he's confident the referendum will succeed.
"I am convinced Tasmanians will vote Yes," he said.
"I will be with the Premier Jeremy Rockliff this morning, and then with Bridget Archer in Launceston this afternoon, both of them being strong Yes supporters."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has called for a review of "corrupt decisions" he says have been made by medical commissions assessing whether conscripts are fit for service in Ukraine's military. He said in his nightly address the number of medical exemptions from military service in some regions had "increased tenfold". He added law enforcement had documented instances of officials receiving bribes worth thousands of dollars. Ukraine introduced a general mobilisation after Russia's February 2022 full-scale invasion and military reservists between the ages of 18 and 60 are eligible for conscription. "It's absolutely clear what kind of decisions these are," he said. "Corrupt decisions."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Zelenskyy calls for review of 'corrupt' conscription decisions

children.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has called for a review of "corrupt decisions" he says have been made by medical commissions assessing whether conscripts are fit for service in Ukraine's military.
He said in his nightly address the number of medical exemptions from military service in some regions had "increased tenfold".
He added law enforcement had documented instances of officials receiving bribes worth thousands of dollars.
Ukraine introduced a general mobilisation after Russia's February 2022 full-scale invasion and military reservists between the ages of 18 and 60 are eligible for conscription.
"It's absolutely clear what kind of decisions these are," he said. "Corrupt decisions."

image.altText: An American flag on a building

items.synopsis: The US economy has continued to cool, raising expectations the Federal Reserve will leave rates on hold next month, while the ASX is set to edge higher at the open on Thursday. Follow live.

title.children: Pause in US interest rate hikes likely as economy cools, Wall Street rallies for fourth day, ASX to rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's not the headline you'll be wanting to see if you're in Victoria or South Australia this morning, but with spring on our doorstep, the energy market operator is warning that much of the national power grid is facing substantial reliability problems in the coming 10 years. The Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO) has released its latest 10-year outlook, and is warning that the outlook for the national grid has worsened since February. AEMO says these reliability problems means "imminent and urgent investment" is needed, or "the reliability of the National Electricity Market (NEM) will be at risk. But it's not just South Australia and Victoria who are facing issues — the NEM includes all states and territories, except for Western Australia and the Northern Territory. So what's behind the reliability problems? A lack of investment in renewable energy generation, storage and transmission as coal-fired power stations shut down. AEMO's chief executive Daniel Westerman says the forecast hotter and dryer summer ahead is a significant risk to the grid. "Breaching the reliability standard doesn't necessarily mean that there will be blackouts ," he told AM. "What it means is that there's not enough electricity supply to meet the standard and that more investment is needed, and that's what we're calling for. "However, we are also saying that this summer, we'll see an elevated risk compared with recent years, and that is primarily because this summer is forecast to be hotter and drier than the last summers. "But it's also because the reliability of our old coal fired generators is at historic lows and plant operators are telling us that that's unlikely to materially improve. "Now, as you'd expect, for this summer, like every summer, AEMO, together with industry and governments are well underway with our preparation to manage these conditions, but we're flagging reliability risks to remain. " You can read more about this story from political reporter Tom Lowrey below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why Victoria and South Australia are at greater risk of power blackouts this summer

featuredLink.title: National energy grid facing peak pressures over hotter months

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Chip maker Nvidia has gone from strength to strength on Wall Street this year, after temporarily becoming a $US1 trillion company in May. Overnight, the tech darling was Wall Street's most traded company, with a whopping $US35.5 billion worth of shares exchanged during the session, gaining 1% at the close. The gain came as a regulatory filing from the company noted the US had expanded the restriction of Nvidia's sophisticated artificial intelligence chips to China and other regions, including some countries in the Middle East. Nvidia hasn't said which countries in the Middle East were affected by this, and hasn't provided a breakout of how much of its revenue comes from the region. In the three months to July 30, Nvidia received most of its $US13.5 billion in sales from the US, China and Taiwan, with 13.9% of its sales from all other countries combined. Nvidia hasn't responded to a request for comment from Reuters, and neither has the US Commerce department, which administers new licensing requirements on exports. "During the second quarter of fiscal year 2024, the USG (US government) informed us of an additional licensing requirement for a subset of A100 and H100 products destined to certain customers and other regions, including some countries in the Middle East," Nvidia said in the filing. One year ago, Nvidia said US officials told it to stop exporting the same two computing chips for AI work to China. — Additional reporting by Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tech darling Nvidia rises by 1pc to close at highest-ever level

children.content: Chip maker
Nvidia
has gone from strength to strength on Wall Street this year, after temporarily becoming a $US1 trillion company in May.
Overnight, the tech darling was Wall Street's most traded company, with a
whopping $US35.5 billion worth of shares
exchanged during the session, gaining 1% at the close.
The gain came as a regulatory filing
from the company noted the US had
expanded the restriction of Nvidia's sophisticated artificial intelligence chips
to China and other regions, including some countries in the Middle East.
Nvidia hasn't said which countries in the Middle East were affected by this, and hasn't provided a breakout of how much of its revenue comes from the region.
In the three months to July 30,
Nvidia received most of its $US13.5 billion in sales from the US, China and Taiwan
, with 13.9% of its sales from all other countries combined.
Nvidia hasn't responded to a request for comment from Reuters, and neither has the US Commerce department, which administers new licensing requirements on exports.

"During the second quarter of fiscal year 2024, the USG (US government) informed us of an additional licensing requirement for a subset of A100 and H100 products destined to certain customers and other regions, including some countries in the Middle East," Nvidia said in the filing.
One year ago, Nvidia said US officials told it to stop exporting the same two computing chips for AI work to China.
— Additional reporting by Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, it's Thursday, August 31 and you're reading the ABC's business and markets blog — it's great to (virtually) see you. Let's start as we always do by looking at Wall Street from overnight, where it was a positive day of trade. The S & P 500 gained 0.4%, the Dow Jones was up 0.1%, and the Nasdaq was 0.5% higher — extending the rally on Wall Street for a fourth day. So what was behind that increase? Weaker than expected data, interestingly enough. Two key pieces of data came out overnight: The ADP employment change was lower than expected, only adding 177,000 jobs; and GDP growth for the second quarter was revised down to 2.1% from 2.4%. Those two figures combined have further solidified expectations that the US Federal Reserve will pause interest rate hikes next month and, as a result, the US economy looks likely to stick to its much discussed "soft landing" scenario (for a local reference, think of the RBA and its "narrow path"). Across the Atlantic in Europe, there was a bit of a mixed result in the markets. The Stoxx600 was lower, the UK market was stronger, while France and Germany were lower. The slight dip in Germany's markets came from weak data, showing a 13.2% drop in imports in the year to July — the sharpest drop since 1981. As for what we can expect locally today? All signs point to a slightly more positive start for the ASX, with futures up slightly to 0.1% as of 7:50am AEST. Plus we've also got some data dropping that will no doubt reverberate across the market — we have housing credit data and private capex (short for capital expenditure) numbers dropping later on in the morning. Feeling up to speed? That's the spirit — grab a coffee, savour this final winter's morning, and stick around to see where the day takes us.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to follow Wall Street's lead with all signs pointing to a positive start
